title: My First Symptom of Fibromyalgia

content: Fibromyalgia is fickle. Medical professionals can’t predict how or when symptoms will start, or why.
For some patients, their first fibromyalgia symptom is fatigue. For others it’s pain. Mine started out in the year 2000 as, bizarrely, numbness and tingling.

I’d just gotten over some sort of flu that lasted several days. I managed to perform in my high school’s production of Hello, Dolly (I was some nameless background dancer/singer, not Dolly), but the exhaustion kept me from doing much else.
It was just a 72-hour “bug.” Other than stress fractures in both legs from playing softball and basketball, I was a healthy teenager. I was sick, and then I got better. No big deal.

Do you know that pins-and-needles sensation you feel when your foot “falls asleep?” Later that same month, my foot fell asleep and wouldn’t “wake up.” Sometimes the tingling felt gentle, sometimes sharp, and sometimes my foot went completely numb.
I tried everything I could think of to make those tingles go away. I tried sitting differently, loosening my shoelaces, walking and jumping, rubbing and poking, and shaking my foot like a maraca.

content_blocks.text: Fibromyalgia is fickle. Medical professionals can’t predict how or when symptoms will start, or why.
For some patients, their first fibromyalgia symptom is fatigue. For others it’s pain. Mine started out in the year 2000 as, bizarrely, numbness and tingling.

I’d just gotten over some sort of flu that lasted several days. I managed to perform in my high school’s production of Hello, Dolly (I was some nameless background dancer/singer, not Dolly), but the exhaustion kept me from doing much else.
It was just a 72-hour “bug.” Other than stress fractures in both legs from playing softball and basketball, I was a healthy teenager. I was sick, and then I got better. No big deal.

Do you know that pins-and-needles sensation you feel when your foot “falls asleep?” Later that same month, my foot fell asleep and wouldn’t “wake up.” Sometimes the tingling felt gentle, sometimes sharp, and sometimes my foot went completely numb.
I tried everything I could think of to make those tingles go away. I tried sitting differently, loosening my shoelaces, walking and jumping, rubbing and poking, and shaking my foot like a maraca.

content: And then, even more bizarrely, the tingling started migrating to my other extremities. It traveled to my hand and fingers and, again, I couldn’t get it to go away. I tried ice, and I tried heat. I cracked my knuckles and tugged on my fingertips. I rotated my hand quickly like a bank robber operating a combination lock and flapped it like a sandy beach towel.
I started tracking the tingling. On Tuesday it would hang out in my left foot but switch to the right on Wednesday. By Friday, it moved to my hand, then changed to the other hand by bedtime.

Eventually it started moving faster, and traveling farther. I’d write in code between my English notes: “LH1” (left hand, 1:00), “RF115” (right foot, 1:15), “LFLA159” (left foot, left arm, 1:59). Sometimes I even felt my back, legs, and face tingle.

content_blocks.text: And then, even more bizarrely, the tingling started migrating to my other extremities. It traveled to my hand and fingers and, again, I couldn’t get it to go away. I tried ice, and I tried heat. I cracked my knuckles and tugged on my fingertips. I rotated my hand quickly like a bank robber operating a combination lock and flapped it like a sandy beach towel.
I started tracking the tingling. On Tuesday it would hang out in my left foot but switch to the right on Wednesday. By Friday, it moved to my hand, then changed to the other hand by bedtime.

Eventually it started moving faster, and traveling farther. I’d write in code between my English notes: “LH1” (left hand, 1:00), “RF115” (right foot, 1:15), “LFLA159” (left foot, left arm, 1:59). Sometimes I even felt my back, legs, and face tingle.

content: I never found a pattern. Wiggling my pinky toe didn’t cause tingling in my right arm. Walking to math class didn’t cause it in my left leg. Drinking milk didn’t move it away from my cheek.

content_blocks.text: I never found a pattern. Wiggling my pinky toe didn’t cause tingling in my right arm. Walking to math class didn’t cause it in my left leg. Drinking milk didn’t move it away from my cheek.

content: And so, the doctor visits began!

A couple of years ago, my mother found my childhood medical records and passed them on to me. According to them, by November of 2000, I had fatigue, headaches, weakness, and lightheadedness in addition to tingling and numbness. I slept frequently but never woke up feeling refreshed.
One doctor described me as “interesting.” Another wrote, “(she) is baffling all my consultants.” A third said I was a “nice young woman,” so there’s that.

I remember stabbing myself with a pencil to stay awake in class. I remember how each month my trombone felt heavier. Twice the lightheadedness hit so hard, so fast, that I collapsed in the school hallway.
On Nov. 10, 2000, a doctor diagnosed me with chronic fatigue syndrome. Almost 3 years and several more symptoms later, including pain, a specialist changed the diagnosis to fibromyalgia.
Now here I sit, 24 years after that first symptom. I don’t experience the tingling and numbness anymore, but there are few things I wouldn’t trade to go back to having that symptom only.
